segments.text: A small hand held hers tightly.
He walked unsteadily, but with his back straight and full of pride.
Just a few days earlier, he had taken his first steps.
He had risen while crawling, trying to reach the ball at the other end of the room.
Stood up, straightened, and started walking toward it as if walking was second nature to him.

She lifted her head, suddenly understanding she was witnessing a defining moment, the wonder of his first steps, and placed her hand over her mouth to avoid startling him with the shout of joy trying to escape her throat.
She watched him walk in the funny duck-like waddle of those first steps, his dart curls bouncing with each stride, her heart reaching out to him.

Then, just before he reached the ball, he stumbled, turned his head to her with a big smile, his blue eyes sparkling like beacons, as if to ensure she had witnessed the miracle, and only then crawled another step to the ball.
She responded with enthusiastic applause, approached him, and lifted him high, murmuring, well done, little boy, well done.
He wrapped his small arms around her neck and kissed her cheek with a wet, resounding kiss as he always did.
Soon after, they were already outside, strolling hand in hand, gently peeping at a passing cat, a snail climbing a bush, and the yellow daisies blooming all around.
She talked to him constantly, not in baby talk, but in grown-up language.
At those moments, he was her only friend, her audience, her cheering crowd, and she was his biggest fan.
She was enchanted by the idea that such an amazing child came from her, perfectly complete.
Even at birth, he tried not to cause too much pain, to make everything seem easy, as if he knew it was already hard for her.
A quick and easy birth, the doctor had said.
And the baby immediately opened a pair of big, bright blue eyes, just like hers, all covered in black hair still stuck to his scalp, which later turned into curls like his father's.
He looked deeply into her eyes, the hint of a small smile rising on his face as if to say, I'm here to ease your solitude, not to burden you.
He was her miracle, the joy of her life, the remedy that helped her overcome the deep longing she felt for Dan.
For four months, she nursed him.
He was close to her in a fabric carrier, sometimes in front, sometimes on her back, throughout the day.
Even cleaning and cooking tasks were done with him attached to her.
Only when he stopped nursing did she let go a little, placing him on a small mattress in the kitchen entrance by the dining room exit.
If he was tired, he would fall asleep there instantly.
Once he learned to crawl, he would make his way to the mattress on his own, lay his head on it, and fall asleep.
At night, she dreamed of Dan, feeling he was speaking to her, asking her to wait patiently for him
not to give up on him, not to give up on them.

In her dreams, he still sat in that same cafe on a colonial-era street, in some Latin quarter, with the same worn beret and beard on his cheeks, as if he were a different man, and only she knew who he really was.
It seemed he was speaking Spanish or Portuguese.
She wasn't sure, but his eyes sparkled when he raised his gaze to her, diving into her.
In the mornings she woke up with a smile.
Ben slept beside her on a mattress she had taken down from the bed since his birth.
Not yet ten months old, he was already beginning to step into the world with his own strides.
She wrote to Dan from the moment she discovered she was pregnant, telling him everything about the feelings in her heart, the anxieties and how she overcame them.

about the guests who filled her small house and brought her joy, about the garden she tended and preserved, so that when he returned, he would see the blossoming pansies and elissum, and if it were early winter, perhaps also witness the sweet pea blooming around the house walls.
Now she tended the garden not only for Lucy, but for Dan as well.
A year and a half had passed since she last saw him, and she still remembered his long kiss, trying to.
Cling to her lips, refusing to let go, and his gaze diving into her eyes, trying to capture every feature of her face so he wouldn't forget.
Before Ben was born, she would write to Dan in her room, leaning against the back of the bed, folding her legs under and placing her notebook on them.
Since Ben was born and slept beside her at night, she would take the white notebook she wrote in and lying on her side with the light from the night lamp.
She would tell him everything she was going through.
Among the simple daily events, stories from her childhood occasionally slipped in, and some of those days she repressed so as not to hurt so much.
On the day Ben took his first steps, she was so excited that she immediately sat down and recorded his every move on paper.
A few days later, when she was already out with him on the path near their home with his small hand holding hers, a memory emerged of her walking just like that on the same path with her mother Lucy.
It seemed to her that it was her first memory.
She wasn't yet three years old and they walked hand in hand on that path between the houses.
She probably dragged her feet and Lucy patiently explained to her that when walking, one should lift their feet after each step, not drag them.
Within a minute, she was marching like a soldier in a parade, lifting foot after foot and seeing the tips of her red shoes that were cut at the toes because they were a bit too small for her.
She relived her childhood through her little son, thrown back in time, exactly between the same walls where she was raising him.
At night, she dreamed she was a very small child, climbing onto the crate of bottles in the kitchen corner and sitting on it, leaning on her small fists, listening in fascination.
Inside the kitchen, amidst the clatter of pots and the sound of frying, Lucy's soft, gentle whistling was heard, whistling entire compositions in all their nuances.
While whistling, she would switch between instruments, moving from violins to piano and double bass, always staying in the correct rhythm for the concert whistled by her private orchestra.
Her eyes opened slowly, her ears still resonating with the wonderful tune, which now, as an adult, she knew was Ravel's Bolero.
It was so vivid, hard to believe it was a dream.
Even the smell of the dishes wafted through her nose.
Rarely did she remember the dreams she dreamed.
And suddenly, here was such a vivid dream remembered down to the smallest details.
For a long while, she lay awake in her bed, hearing in her mind Lucy's absolute pitch whistling.
Music accompanied her mother and kept her company throughout the day.

From the moment she arrived, early in the morning, there was always something playing in the background, from the radio or the record player placed on a shelf behind the bar, with a special collection of classical music records and the best singers.
Sinatra, Maria Callis, Aznavour, Yves Montan,
and all gently, not blaring loudly.
There was also the big cumbersome radio, with its yellowing fabric and large knobs, which would emit a slight squeak when turned.
It was placed on a shelf close to their table, the one closest to the kitchen exit.
There they would sit to eat, or just with a cup of tea or coffee.
Joseph would read the newspaper and listen to the news there.
Lucy used that device not just to listen to music.
Once a day, exactly at 2 and 10 minutes, right after the news bulletin ended, Lucy would come out of the kitchen, fold her apron, light a cigarette, and sit at their table, very close to the radio.
She would lean forward, a concentrated expression on her face, listening intently, perhaps hoping for some information about her sister Ida.
a little lost soul, Idaka, or as they called her at home, Daka.
After about twenty minutes, the Department for Seeking Relatives program would end, and she would sigh a deep sigh, lean back and light a new cigarette.
Thousands like her were scattered in those years throughout our small country, searching for loved ones lost during and after the Holocaust.
trying to peace families back together.

Sometimes a little girl, five or six years old, would sit next to her on a chair, like the one on the crate of bottles from the dream, mimicking her mother's seating, leaning slightly as well, adopting a serious expression and listening.
Mordecai Rabinovits from Kovno, searching for Rachel Rabinovits.
Erin Eisenstadt from Chavli, Lithuania, searching for Deborah, daughter of Abraham Eisenstadt.
She didn't fully understand what she was hearing and once asked Lucy, Manny, what are you listening to?
Her mother told her she had a little sister and she was looking for her.
Did she get lost?
She asked.
Yes, she got lost.
But in the end, I will find her," her mother replied.
Lucy had come to the country alone in 1936.
In 1937, she managed a short visit back to her parents and met her sister and husband.
She tried to persuade them to come to join her, but her father wasn't enthusiastic about the idea.
True, he said, there are some problems, but the Shirt Factory is doing well and provides a good living.
In the winter of 1939, the sisters of the Kruger family nearly simultaneously each gave birth to their first daughter, one in Tel Aviv and the other in Warsaw.

A year later, when the Germans were already at Warsaw's doorstep, Ida and her husband fled with their infant less than a year old on a motorcycle towards the Russian border, and they hadn't been heard from since.
Someone once hinted that her husband was killed immediately at the start.
While Ida survived, but there was no sign to confirm this, the parents refused to flee with them.
And in 1942, they were sent to Treblinka and murdered there.
Thus, as part of a regular ritual, Lucy would sit to listen to the department for seeking relatives.
Lucia of the Kruger family was searching for her sister Eda, daughter of Zygmunt Kruger.
One day, information began arriving from somewhere via the acquaintances, suggesting that Eda was indeed alive in Poland.
They provided her address, and a correspondence began between her and her sister.
Thus, the story began to unfold.
Alek, her husband, was shot shortly after their escape.
She continued to flee with the baby in her arms, with a group of Jews, thereby saving herself.
She eventually remarried and had another daughter.
Lucy was beside herself.
It was as if she had been given an additional purpose in life.
Almost twenty years without seeing each other, she never gave up during all those years.
Twenty years is a long time, but for her, it was as if time had stood still.
Suddenly, she had a little sister again.
A year passed until they made their way by ship to Haifa.
All that year, Lucy sent her sister parcels of clothes, delicacies, baskets, and other items that could be sold for money.
They were allowed to bring only their household belongings, and oddly enough, a piano was included.
Thus the money was partly exchanged to bring a piano at Lucy's request because the little one has a wonderful ear.
One morning, when she was only eight, the door opened and at the entrance stood her beautiful and upright aunt.
Her short hair dyed blonde, with her uncle with kind eyes and two lovely cousins.
One was already grown, and the other, a beautiful ten-year-old with an upturned nose and a braid down to her waist, had already been in a film and could beat any adult at chess.
And shortly after, the piano arrived.
That's what Lucy left her, she thought, the musical ear.
Her eyes and what lay within them.
She lay in bed awake.
Still hearing Lucy's whistling, echoing in her ears, her eyes wide open, aware of the slight smile on her lips, knowing it was a good dream, a dream of music and memories of loss and reality.
In the evening, she wrote to Dan about Lucy's whistling.
She told him how Lucy would call her back home with the whistle of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.
When you return, we'll have a whistle too," she added in her notebook.
We'll decide together what it will be, and so we will whistle to Ben-Ben and each other.
In her mind's eye, she already saw him standing and whistling.
